Dialogue.NPCText:
You are met with the blistering heat of a magical fire as a striking woman stands before you, her copper hair ablaze in the windless air.
Her boots leave faint scorch-marks on the floating crystal beneath her. Embers dance along her Emberwoven Chemise and the fiery Crown of Searing Insight.

“You tread close to the outer ring, where only those with courage—or the sense to keep clear—walk. I am Syla Margrave, Pyromancer of Aerilon. If you’re here to whine about the warmth, leave. If you’re here to help, speak quickly—my time, like flame, is precious.”

Option.text: I’m looking for work—do you have need of an agent?
Why is it so hot out here?
What is your role in Aerilon?
I want to know more about you.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Syla narrows her eyes, flames flickering at her fingertips.
“Aerilon’s outer ring is held in check by my fire conduit array—brilliant, dangerous, and recently... unreliable.
The conduits burn out faster than Salia Moontide can engineer excuses. Sabotage? Leyline rot? Or someone with a grudge against me, which is a longer list than you’d think.
If you want to earn Aerilon’s favor, I have a delivery that requires subtlety, speed, and a taste for danger. Up for it?”

Syla cracks a wry grin.
“Heat keeps the crystals flowing, the conduits alive, and nosy politicians at bay. Some say I’m too blunt—better that than smothered by the cold obsessions of Salia Moontide and her ilk.
Besides, fire keeps Aerilon afloat—let them grumble. I’d sooner duel a volcano than let these flames die.”

Option.text: Tell me more about your work.
Sounds like you and Salia clash often.
I should leave you to it.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Pyromancer of the Outer Ring, guardian of the Flame Array, and, apparently, part-time diplomat to anyone who can’t tell a leyline from a fuse.
I keep the city’s southern conduits from burning out. If Salia Moontide’s crystal engines fail, my fire arrays buy us hours. If mine fail... let’s not dwell on that.
I mentored Lira Veyra, once. She has the heart of a firestorm, but Corvus is steering her toward battle, not balance. Waste of raw talent, in my view.”

Syla shrugs, smoke trailing from her shoulders.
“You’ll find no shade nor patience here. If you change your mind, return before the next conduit fails—and bring water.”

Option.text: On second thought, do you have work?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Syla’s tone smolders.
“Salia is brilliant, but her faith in mechanisms is a brittle thing. Fire doesn’t follow blueprints—it’s alive, unpredictable.
We butt heads because she fears what she can’t quantify. Still, when the city’s on the brink, she calls me. Always. Even if she’ll never admit it.”

Option.text: It sounds like you respect her.
How does that rivalry help Aerilon?
Enough about her. What’s the task?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Syla’s eyes soften for a flicker of a second.
“Respect, sure. Friendship? Not likely. But every good fire needs a vessel. Salia tempers my flame, and sometimes, I force her to take risks. Keeps us both sharp.”

“Aerilon thrives on creative tension. If we agreed on everything, the city would be a cinder or a glacier. Our rivalry keeps the conduits running and the Conclave guessing.
Now—about that job…”

Syla nods, pride flickering in her gaze.
“Lira Veyra—yes, she trained under me before Corvus poached her for his martial nonsense. She understands fire, not just in spellwork, but in spirit.
I just hope she doesn’t lose that spark fighting other people’s wars. Aerilon needs mages who remember why we soared above the world in the first place.”

Option.text: Perhaps you’ll mentor again. What’s the job?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Syla lowers her voice, gaze narrowing.
“Sabotage? Maybe. We’ve lost three conduits in two weeks. Salia blames leylines. I suspect a more human hand—possibly Minax’s cultists or a rival mage.
Delivering this item could flush out a traitor… or at least get my mind off conspiracies.”

Option.text: Tell me more about the delivery.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“If I leave the ring, my rivals seize the chance to meddle. Besides, no one expects a stranger to carry something vital for me. It’s subtlety—or as close as I get to subtlety.
Outsiders aren’t bound by Conclave politics. That’s your edge.”

Syla grins.
“Rep with Aerilon—and a favor from the Outer Ring’s pyromancer. That opens doors you can’t even see yet.
Gold is for merchants and moles. My gratitude is rarer.”

Option.text: Good enough. Tell me what to do.
I was hoping for coin. Maybe later.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Syla produces a **Phoenixfire Ember Core**—a swirling, rune-inscribed ember held in a heatproof vial.
“This is the Ember Core. With it, a Satyr Specialist outside the city can tune our fire conduits, stabilize leylines, and root out any tampering.
But the trait is crucial—Satyrs have a touch for wild magic and won’t be easily fooled by saboteurs.
Deliver the Core, watch your back, and don’t open the vial unless you want a new career as a pile of ash. Do this, and Aerilon—and I—will owe you.”

Option.text: Give me the Ember Core. I’ll deliver it.
What’s the risk on this errand?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Syla hands you the heatproof vial.
“Take it to the Satyr Specialist. When it’s done, return for your reward—and a story to tell.
If anyone tries to take the Ember Core, burn the ground behind you. Trust no one with goat’s eyes or silver tongues.
Go! I have conduits to repair.”

Option.text: I’ll guard it with my life.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Satyr Specialists—eccentric, wild, but no one tunes elemental fire like they do. Half-mage, half-musician, they see the world in harmonies and patterns the rest of us miss.
If you find one who’ll speak to you, you’ll know by the way the flames behave around their hands. Only they can fix what’s wrong—and perhaps uncover the traitor’s tricks.”

Option.text: I understand. I’ll do the delivery.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Syla’s eyes flash with anger.
“Minax’s reach is long—and she hates Aerilon’s flame. Her agents love sowing chaos where the conduits run hottest.
This delivery keeps us one step ahead. Fail, and we may see the city fall—literally.”

Option.text: Then I’ll make sure it gets there.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Syla leans in, her tone low and fierce.
“There’s always risk. The last courier was found with singed eyebrows and a story about a shapechanger with Minax’s mark.
Use your head. If someone tries to intercept you, throw the vial in running water. It’ll vanish and reappear on my workbench, safe but wasted.
But if you succeed—you’ll have my gratitude. That’s rarer than gold in this city.”

Option.text: I accept the risk and the task.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Syla folds her arms, heat rippling in the air around her.
“Curious, are you? Most just want spells or errands. But fine—if you insist on peeling back the layers, don’t flinch at the burn.
What exactly do you want to know?”

Option.text: Where did you train in the arcane arts?
What does fire mean to you?
Do you have any personal rivals besides Salia?

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Wind. Yes, *that* Wind. I trained there before the Conclave even existed. Back when mages sat in silence and called it wisdom.
I set a classroom on fire—accidentally. They called it recklessness. I called it... foreshadowing.
Archmage Selara offered me exile or elevation. I chose flame.”

Option.text: Selara gave you a second chance?
Sounds like Wind never understood you.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Selara values talent over tradition, and that saved me. She doesn’t *like* me, but she *respects* the fire I bring.
I suppose we share that: we both left Wind behind and built something impossible in the sky.”

Option.text: You and Selara have more in common than you'd admit.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Wind sees magic as an equation. I see it as a living storm. Their halls are libraries; mine are forges.
Maybe one day I’ll torch their index cards. Just kidding. Mostly.”

Option.text: That fire still burns in you.

Dialogue.NPCText: “Luck had nothing to do with it. I earned every spark in my soul—and singed half a dozen robes to prove it.”

“Serve? No. I *chose* Aerilon. I helped forge the first flame conduits with my bare hands and unshielded mind.
Most would’ve died. I nearly did. But when the first rings rose into the air, I felt... home.
This place doesn’t just float on crystals—it floats on sacrifice.”

Option.text: You’re more than a mage—you’re a founder.

Dialogue.NPCText: “Love it? No. I *belong* to it. There’s a difference. Fire doesn’t love; it consumes. And if Aerilon fails, my flame goes with it.”
“I didn’t sign papers or give speeches. But when this city first rose, my blood was in the stone. The conduits still hum with it.”

Option.text: Sounds like your soul is baked into the place.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Fire isn’t destruction. It’s *transformation*. Burn a tree, and you release the sunlight trapped in it. Burn an idea, and you test its truth.
I don’t wield fire. I *negotiate* with it. Every day.”

Option.text: I never thought of fire that way.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Rivals? I collect them like kindling.
There’s a blood witch in Frostmere who tried to siphon power from our leylines. A satyr illusionist who challenged me to a duel of metaphors. I won. With a haiku.
And Corvus Deyne? He’s not a rival. He’s a warning label with teeth.”

“Ash floats in the sky
Words like flame must dance or die
Silence burns the lie.”

Option.text: Did it actually win you the duel?

Dialogue.NPCText:
“The satyr wept. Said no one had burned him that gently before. Then he gave me his sandals and vanished into fog.
I still wear them to this day—when I want to be unpredictable.”

Syla leans closer, eyes glittering.
“Here’s something no one in the Conclave knows: I can’t cook. At all. Fire obeys me, but broth? No chance. I once ignited a stew *from inside the ladle*.”
She snorts. “That’s why I trade spellwork for meals with Tolan Drift. He makes a killer sea-stew. Don’t tell him I said that.”

Option.text: Trade you a stew for a spell?
I’ll be sure to tell Tolan.
